awd_titl_txt: Southern California Geometric Analysis Seminar, Winter 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support for the 28th Southern California Geometric Analysis Seminar (SCGAS) meeting, which will be held on March 4-5, 2023 at the University of California - Irvine. The SCGAS is an annual two-day conference that rotates between the University of California - Irvine and the University of California - San Diego. The conference features talks given by acclaimed researchers and promotes interactions among members of the Southern California mathematics community working in the field of geometric analysis and related areas. It further seeks to introduce to graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to some of the most exciting recent developments in geometric analysis. Conference organizers will actively support and encourage the participation of graduate students and recent Ph.D.s, especially members of underrepresented groups.
 
Geometric analysis is an important area of modern mathematics and is related to many other branches of mathematics. Using analysis as its main tool along with differential geometry, topology, and algebraic geometry as foundations, geometric analysis has solved a large number of problems in global geometry, topology, several complex variables and mathematical physics. As the prior success of this series has demonstrated, the SCGAS conference has now become an important and anticipated event for the Southern California region and has also attracted a substantial number of participants from the rest of the country each year. It continues to foster interests in geometric analysis at all levels. In the years past, interactions among the participants during the conference have led to a number of new collaborations and research projects. The web site for the 28th Southern California Geometric Analysis Seminar may be found at https://www.math.uci.edu/~scgas/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Regents of the University of California Irvine

por.por_cntn:
This award provided support for the 28th Southern California Geometric Analysis Seminar (SCGAS) meeting, which was held on March 4-5, 2023 at the University of California - Irvine. A follow-up seminar was held on May 28, 2024 to further discuss research results from the main conference.The research topics included Ricci curvature, Ricci flow, minimal hypersurfaces, the SYZ conjecture, Higgs-Coulomb correspondence, mean curvature flow, curve-shortening flow, and general relativity.

The SCGAS is an annual two-day conference that rotates between the University of California - Irvine and the University of California - San Diego. The conference featured talks given by acclaimed researchers and promotes interactions among members of the Southern California mathematics community working in the field of geometric analysis and related areas. It further seeked to introduce to graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to some of the most exciting recent developments in geometric analysis. Conference organizers actively supported and encouraged the participation of graduate students and recent Ph.D.s.

Geometric analysis is an important area of modern mathematics and is related to many other branches of mathematics. Using analysis as its main tool along with differential geometry, topology, and algebraic geometry as foundations, geometric analysis has solved a large number of problems in global geometry, topology, several complex variables and mathematical physics. As the prior success of this series has demonstrated, the SCGAS conference has now become an important and anticipated event for the Southern California region and has also attracted a substantial number of participants from the rest of the country each year. It continues to foster interests in geometric analysis at all levels. In the years past, interactions among the participants during the conference have led to a number of new collaborations and research projects. The web site for the Southern California Geometric Analysis Seminar may be found at https://scgas.math.uci.edu/
